item.title: Dollar Bounce Is Short-Lived After Trump Tariffs Move Into Limbo
item.description: The long-term bearish case for the dollar remained intact after a court ruled that the vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global trade tariffs are illegal, amplifying uncertainty over the US economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Ruth Carson, Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Pimco’s Stracke Sees Asset-Based Finance as Key Driver of Growth
item.description: Christian Stracke, president and global head of credit research at Pacific Investment Management Co. (Pimco), says the firm is building out its investments in asset-based finance to meet client demands, “that’s an area that’s really picking up speed in terms of the availability of finance outside of banks.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Acrisure Goes Big on Payroll With $1.1B Acquisition
item.description: Michigan-based Acrisure is agreeing to buy Heartland Payroll Solutions from Global Payments for $1.1 billion. The insurance broker is trying to be a one-stop shop for fintech services. Acrisure CEO and C-Founder Greg Williams joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the deal and what's ahead. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Telefonica Chairman’s M&A Ambitions Face Old Debt Challenges
item.description: Telefonica SA’s new chairman is running into an old problem. After the better part of a decade focused on cutting debt, the company still doesn’t have the cash it needs to chase deals and growth.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga, Vinicy Chan

media:content.media:description: Marc Murtra, chief executive officer of Telefonica SA, delivers a keynote speech at the MWC25 tech show in Barcelona, Spain, on Monday, March 3, 2024. The Mobile World Congress tech show runs March 3-6.

item.title: Pimco’s Stracke on Tariffs, Areas of Growth, Yield Curve
item.description: Christian Stracke, president and global head of credit research at Pacific Investment Management Co. (Pimco), discusses market reaction to a court ruling on President Donald Trump’s tariff policy, his concerns about borrowing by sub-investment grade companies, and growth in asset-based finance. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: India’s LIC Sole Buyer in Adani Ports’ Record Rupee Bond Sale
item.description: Life Insurance Corp. of India is the sole buyer in Adani Ports & Special Economic Zone Ltd.’s record 50-billion-rupee ($585 million) bond sale, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das, Divya Patil

item.title: UniCredit Pays Over €600 Million for New Alpha Bank Stake
item.description: UniCredit SpA paid slightly more than €600 million ($677 million) to double its stake in Greece’s Alpha Services and Holdings SA, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas, Sonia Sirletti

media:content.media:description: An Alpha Bank branch in Athens. Photographer: Yorgos Karahalis/Bloomberg

item.title: Pimco’s Stracke Has Concerns About Floating Rate Borrowers
item.description: Christian Stracke, president and global head of credit research at Pacific Investment Management Co. (Pimco), discusses his concerns about below-investment grade companies borrowing in floating rate loans and what it would take to see an increase in defaults in that part of the credit market. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Saudi Hospital Operator Claws Back Dividends During IPO Process
item.description: Specialized Medical Co., which operates hospitals in Saudi Arabia, is set to close the institutional books for its initial public offering after existing shareholders agreed to return recently paid dividends and the company issued a revised prospectus.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta

media:content.media:description: Stethoscope is a medical device to check heart beats and The lungs health

item.title: Pimco’s Stracke Sees Asset-Based Finance as Key Area of Growth
item.description: Pacific Investment Management Co. is building out its investments in asset-based finance to meet client demands to diversify away from more traditional areas of private credit.
item.dc:creator: Dani Burger, Kat Hidalgo, Ronan Martin

media:content.media:description: Pacific Investment Management Co. (Pimco) headquarters in Newport Beach, California.

item.title: US Futures Rally on Tariff Ruling; Nvidia Jumps 6%: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks climbed, with S&P 500 futures up 1.5%, after a court ruling blocked some of President Donald Trump’s import tariffs and Nvidia Corp. posted another set of blockbuster results.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Lynn Thomasson

media:content.media:description: Cleo Capital Managing Director Sarah Kunst says Nvidia's Jensen Huang is the "best-suited CEO" to deal with the recent US-China trade tensions on "Bloomberg The Close." Nvidia said sales will be about $45 billion in the second fiscal quarter. That included the loss of roughly $8 billion in revenue from China because of export controls.

item.title: India Bank Frauds Triple to $4.2 Billion as Credit Scams Swell
item.description: Bank frauds in India jumped threefold last year, with loans contributing to bulk of the cases, while discrepancies in digital payments declined.
item.dc:creator: Advait Palepu, Sidhartha Shukla

item.title: ECB’s Kazimir Convicted of Bribery and Given €200,000 Fine
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Peter Kazimir was found guilty of bribery and fined €200,000 ($225,380), becoming the first Slovak governor to get convicted.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

item.title: European Gas Fluctuates as Traders Weigh Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: European natural gas swung between gains and losses as traders weighed the impact of a US court decision to block President Donald Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

item.title: Li Auto Second-Quarter Sales Set to Disappoint Amid EV Price War
item.description: Li Auto Inc. forecast second-quarter revenue that fell short of what investors are expecting, as the Chinese electric vehicle maker struggles amid intensifying competition in the world’s biggest automobile market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Li Auto L6 at the Beijing Auto Show

item.title: Riskier Fringes of Market Are Leaving Blue-Chip Stocks Behind
item.description: The riskiest corners of the US stock market are on pace for the biggest gain since November relative to larger and more stable peers, a vote of confidence in the economy’s resilience amid uncertainty about tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during the Hinge Health Inc. initial public offering (IPO) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 22, 2025. Hinge Health Inc. and a group of investors raised $437 million in the digital physical therapy provider's US initial public offering, pricing shares at the top of a marketed range.

item.title: Gold Steadies as Investors Weigh Impact of Trump Tariff Ruling
item.description: Gold steadied as markets absorbed news that the US trade court has blocked President Donald Trump’s global tariff agenda.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

item.title: Kazakhstan Says It Can’t Cut Oil Output Despite OPEC+ Deal
item.description: Kazakhstan said it can’t cut oil production right now, and even hopes to increase output beyond planned levels later this year, deepening a stand-off with its OPEC+ counterparts.
item.dc:creator: Nariman Gizitdinov, Grant Smith

media:content.media:description: A pumping unit draws oil at a field in Kazakhstan.

item.title: Oil Climbs in Risk-On Mood as Trade Court Blocks Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Oil advanced alongside equity markets after a US trade court blocked many of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, deeming them illegal.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

item.title: UAE’s Flagship Crude Oil Sees Record Volume as OPEC+ Adds Supply
item.description: Trading activity in United Arab Emirates’ flagship crude has surged this month to the highest on record, as OPEC+ raises supply quotas.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Alex Longley

item.title: Microsoft Shares Go From Laggard to Leader as AI Growth Improves
item.description: After languishing for months, Microsoft Corp. shares are back within striking distance of a record high amid signs that performance in its Azure cloud-computing business is back on track.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: BP’s Castrol Unit Draws Interest From Reliance, Apollo and Lone Star
item.description: BP Plc’s Castrol lubricant business is attracting interest from energy companies including Reliance Industries Ltd. and buyout firms such as Apollo Global Management Inc. and Lone Star Funds, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Dinesh Nair, Mitchell Ferman, Jack Farchy, Claire Ruckin

item.title: Goldman Says Trump Can Offset Tariff Ruling With Other Tools
item.description: A court ruling that seeks to block President Donald Trump’s “Liberation Day” tariffs represents only a temporary setback to his trade agenda and can be offset by other taxes, according to analysts at Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Ken Cedeno/UPI

item.title: Morgan Stanley Denies Dutch Prosecutor’s Tax Evasion Allegations
item.description: Morgan Stanley denied allegations by the Dutch Public Prosecution Service that it evaded tax on almost $1 billion worth of dividends more than a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Hughes-Morgan

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians pass along a walkway between high-rise buildings in the Zuidas financial district in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Thursday, June 18, 2020. The Dutch economy is expected to start recovering “slowly but steadily” from middle of year, with GDP expected to increase 2.9% in 2021 and 2.4% in 2022, the country’s central bank said in a statement with half-yearly estimates. Photographer: Yuriko Nakao/Bloomberg

item.title: Rixos Hotels Bets on Gulf Boom With $3 Billion Qatar Project
item.description: The Turkish owner of the Rixos Hotels is expanding beyond Europe and Central Asia to bet big on the Gulf with a $3 billion investment in Qatar’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Zainab Fattah

media:content.media:description: A rendering of The Land of Legends theme park in Qatar.

item.title: A $135 Billion Bond Market Lures Issuers Too Risky for Banks
item.description: Oil and coal issuers struggling to get bank loans are increasingly turning to a little-known corner of the bond market hidden away in one of the planet’s greenest economic zones.
item.dc:creator: Natasha White

media:content.media:description: Commercial blocks sit in Oslo, Norway.

item.title: JPMorgan Sees Asia Deals on the Horizon in Volatile Markets
item.description: Dealmaking in Asia Pacific is looking pretty buoyant as companies assess the best places to allocate capital in volatile times, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co.’s head of investment banking in the region, Paul Uren.
item.dc:creator: Manuel Baigorri

media:content.media:description: Paul Uren Source: JPMorgan Chase & Co.

item.title: Positive Returns Possible, But Volatile: Shah
item.description: Seema Shah, chief global strategist at Principal Asset Management, discusses the market reaction after a US court blocked the bulk of President Donald Trump's import tariffs. "I don't think this is the end of the tariff story," she tells Bloomberg Television. Shah says she expects "an economic slowdown" but not a recession. "You can still get positive returns this year. It's just going to be something which is fairly volatile, very erratic, but it will be an upward-sloping move in the end." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Take Day Off If You're Bearish US Stocks: 3-Minute MLIV
item.description: Anna Edwards, Guy Johnson, Kriti Gupta and Mark Cudmore break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Aramco Boss Plans to Keep Borrowing After $14 Billion Haul
item.description: Saudi Aramco is targeting more borrowing to finance growth and better leverage its balance sheet, Chief Executive Officer Amin Nasser said, as the world’s biggest oil exporter raised $5 billion in bonds this week.
item.dc:creator: Joumanna Bercetche, Anthony Di Paola

media:content.media:description: Amin Nasser Photographer: F. Carter Smith/Bloomberg
